title: Immokalee Regional Airport
text:
Immokalee Regional Airport is a public use <a href="airport">airport</a> located one <a href="nautical%20mile">nautical mile</a> (2 <a href="kilometre">km</a>) northeast of the <a href="central%20business%20district">central business district</a> of <a href="Immokalee%2C%20Florida">Immokalee</a>, in <a href="Collier%20County%2C%20Florida">Collier County, Florida</a>, United States. The airport is owned by the Collier County Airport Authority. Formerly known as Immokalee Airport, it is included in the <a href="National%20Plan%20of%20Integrated%20Airport%20Systems">National Plan of Integrated Airport Systems</a> for 2011–2015, which <a href="FAA%20airport%20categories">categorized</a> it as a "<a href="general%20aviation">general aviation</a>" facility.
History.
Established as Immokalee Army Airfield, activated on July 5, 1942. Assigned to <a href="United%20States%20Army%20Air%20Forces">United States Army Air Forces</a> East Coast Training Center (later Eastern Training Command). Was an auxiliary to <a href="Hendricks%20Army%20Airfield">Hendricks Army Airfield</a> and was an AAF Specialized Pilot Training School (4-Engine) for B-17 and B-24 heavy bombers. Also provided flexible gunnery training for <a href="Buckingham%20Army%20Airfield">Buckingham Army Airfield</a> near <a href="Fort%20Myers">Fort Myers</a>.
Transferred to <a href="Third%20Air%20Force">Third Air Force</a> in July 1944 with the drawdown of AAFTC's pilot training program and was a group training facility for replacement personnel. Became an auxiliary of the <a href="Sarasota%20Army%20Airfield">Sarasota Army Airfield</a> replacement fighter pilot training school.
Declared surplus and turned over to the Army Corps of Engineers on September 30, 1945. Eventually discharged to the <a href="War%20Assets%20Administration">War Assets Administration</a> (WAA) and became a civil airport.
Facilities and aircraft.
Immokalee Regional Airport covers an area of 1,330 <a href="acre">acre</a>s (538 <a href="hectare">ha</a>) at an <a href="elevation">elevation</a> of 37 feet (11 m) above <a href="mean%20sea%20level">mean sea level</a>. It has two <a href="asphalt">asphalt</a> paved <a href="runway">runway</a>s, designated 9/27 and 18/36. 9/27 is 5,000 x 100 feet (1,524 x 30 m) and 18/36 is 5,000 x 150 feet (1,524 x 46 m).
For the 12-month period ending October 22, 2013, the airport had 36,500 <a href="general%20aviation">general aviation</a> aircraft operations, an average of 100 per day. At that time there were 60 aircraft based at this airport: 45 single-<a href="aircraft%20engine">engine</a>, 9 multi-engine, 4 <a href="jet%20aircraft">jet</a>, and 2 <a href="helicopter">helicopter</a>.
